My kwentong jeepney:
I was in Diliman and sumakay ako ng jeep na pa-Quezon Av. Umupo ako sa tabi ni Manong Driver and nagkwentuhan pa kame. Sobrang bangag ko from work, bumaba ako ng jeep without giving my bayad. Wondering why may barya sa pocket ko which is intended for the fare

In protest of the PUV Modernization Program‚Äôs allegedly inaccurate jeepney consolidation figures presented by LTO and DOT.

üö® For many jeepney drivers, today's big-time oil price hike translates to daily fuel expenses soaring to approximately P1,800 ‚Äî an amount that exceeds both the NCR minimum wage of P645 and the family living wage of P1,200.

This is further compounded by regressive taxes on fuel such as VAT and excise tax that disproportionately affect the poor while allowing billionaires to benefit from tax breaks. PISTON estimates that jeepney drivers have lost around a total of P6,400 of income due to these oil taxes since the beginning of the year. 

READ MORE ‚û°Ô∏è https://t.co/sODDtkU9rl

Dahil sa mga jeepney drivers, mayroong makabuluhan at matipid na paraan ng transportasyon sa harap ng siklo ng walang patid na pag-taas ng pamumuhay. Kasabay nito, patuloy rin ang panawagan natin para sa tunay na living wage at patuloy na pagtutol sa charter change.

More labor unions unite in Morayta to showcase their calls for living wage, with jeepney drivers call to junk the PUV Modernization Program.

If 1 jeepney can ferry 192 passengers per day then that‚Äôs 11.9M passengers per day IF all 62k NCR jeepneys are on the road at the same time (they are not for obvious reasons). There must be a way to make it more efficient & give a living wage for everyone in the transport sector.

if a new jeepney costs 1M & driver would be borrowing money to pay for it. if loan is for 5 years then 1000000/5/12 = 16,666 /mo. PHP757 /day. at PHP20 per passenger that's 40 passengers only for loan. No gasoline, living wage, maintenance or other fees. PHP50 is not unreasonable

Jeepney drivers do not even earn enough money that is equivalent to  the living wage; It is still not enough to meet their basic necessities everyday yet you're planning to execute this impractical plan?

LOOK: Jeepney drivers in Caloocan City are lamenting reduced income following another significant oil price hike implemented on Tuesday, 21 September.

Bladdy, a driver on the MCU-Fishermall route, shared that he plans to cut back on food expenses to ensure he can still bring home money for his family.

Diesel prices rose by P2.70 per liter, gasoline by P1.65 per liter, and kerosene by P2.50 per liter. This marks the third consecutive week of price increases for diesel and gasoline. | Aljon Eguia

#OilPriceHike #DailyTribune
